speaker: Unknown
message: आई वी एम

speaker: Amit Varma
message: इरी प्र कापिटा जीडि पे विल गो अप Another economist says that As all of the victims were unemployed India's unemployment rate just went down All thanks to dear leader Another economist calculates The productivity gains for all those Who would've spent a couple of minutes Interacting with these beggars And now don't have to because they're dead These economists give themselves high-fives And tell dear leader that he should Kill more beggars Meanwhile the journalist manages to whimper But how can you do cost-benefit analysis in a situation like this? What economic benefit could justify the moral cost? They immediately arrest the journalist for being an urban naxal And one of them bends down to massage dear leader's foot Which is aching from pressing the accelerator so hard All for the good of the nation

speaker: Unknown
message: Welcome to The Seen and The Unseen Our weekly podcast on economics, politics and behavioral science Please welcome your host, Amit Badma

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Welcome to The Seen and The Unseen Today's episode is about demonetization A subject on which I have done a couple of episodes in the past You can look for them in our archives at seenunseen.in This episode is sparked by the RBI finally releasing the data On how much of the demonetized currency came back into the banking system 15.3 trillion rupees or 99.3% That basically is one final metric of the policy failure of demon As we call it now As if we needed any more metrics And my guest to talk about this today will be Shruti Rajgopalan But before I get to my conversation with her Allow me a small rant Because this is a subject I feel very very strongly about Right after demonetization was announced I wrote a bunch of pieces about how it was such a blunder They will all be linked on the page for this episode at thinkragati.com or seenunseen.in It was evident to me at the start That demon was wrong from both a moral and an economic lens In a piece I wrote for the Times of India shortly after demon was announced I pointed out the economic problems with it One, Modi claimed it was an attack on black money But this was nonsense The government's own estimates showed That only 6% of black money was kept in the form of cash The rest was gold or real estate or foreign accounts and so on Two, Modi said that demon would help fight counterfeit currency But the government's own estimates showed That only 1 in 4000 notes was fake Which is normal by standards across the world And which governments usually fight successfully by phasing out old notes Three, Modi said that terrorist activities would be hurt by this But cross-border terrorism has actually gone up in this time Leave alone domestic terrorism by gaurakshaks Four, Modi later said that this would help digitalization But data since is shown that digitalization Has followed the same upward trend it was on before demon And people are now back to using cash in the same way that they were before Also it's unclear why digitization is such a good thing anyway So none of the economic benefits were going to pan out anyway Now what about the costs? There are two kinds of costs here Economic costs and moral costs The economic costs were quite obvious If you remove 86% of the currency in use Where cash transactions are 97% of all transactions The economy will be crushed There are numerous estimates and descriptions of the damage that Narendra Modi did And I will point out one specifically striking figure to you My friend Nitin Pai first mentioned this That every 1% rise in the GDP Brings 2 million people out of poverty The opportunity cost of demonetization is much more than this And naturally the rich were hurt the least They used their connections to launder their money One indication of that being automobile sales in the months following demon They fell for 2 wheelers and 3 wheelers But remained steady for high end SUVs But forget the economic cost Let's talk about the moral cost When millions of people find out that much of their money is worthless And they have to queue up outside banks for hours and days for their own money What else is that if not theft? What else is that if not violence? More than a 100 people died directly because of demonetization And I consider them people murdered by Narendra Modi These include Jagdish Panwar The tea seller from Sikar in Rajasthan Who had a heart attack brought on by the fact That he suddenly did not have money for his daughter's wedding These include Halke Loti The farmer from Chattarpur in Madhya Pradesh Who killed himself because he didn't have money to buy fertilizer and seeds In time for the sowing season These include the unnamed 55 year old woman from Telangana Who killed herself because the 54 lakh she had saved over a lifetime Was now worthless These include the newborn child who died in Mumbai Because a hospital refused to accept the newly demonetized notes And so on and on and on These are human beings not statistics Beyond these deaths Businesses shut down in the informal economy Because it runs mainly on cash Livelihoods were destroyed Years of hard work were wiped out in one evening I call it the largest assault on private property in human history It was a crime on humanity And there were people who tried to do a cost benefit analysis of this They claimed that the economic benefits justified the moral cost Leave aside the fact that there were no economic benefits And this was an economic disaster as well But even if there were benefits Can you play with the lives of people like this? Would it be right to use even one person in this manner As a means to an end? Narendra Modi did this to every citizen of this country Modi is a delusional megalomaniac There is nothing new to say on him But what really makes me angry is The supposedly respectable economists and public intellectuals Who supported demonetization Many of them were rewarded for this With positions in the Prime Minister's Economic Advisory Council In Niti Aayog and so on I personally know different economists who worked in government And were ordered to defend demonetization Even though they personally thought it was a disaster They should have refused But they defended it And all these people who defended this crime on humanity With its massive moral and economic costs How do we describe them? Are they bad economists? Well, duh! And are they also bad human beings? Which is a more charitable explanation? I view demonetization as a litmus test For both sound economic thinking And basic human decency Demon was indefensible But I won't rant about that anymore Because I might burst a vein or something Something dear leader would not mind at all I have a bunch of links on the page for this episode Which lists out all my writing on the subject Do check them out In the meantime It's time for me to bring on my guest for today's episode My friend, the brilliant Shruti Rajgopalan But before that Let's take a quick commercial break Like me, are you someone who loves fine art But can't really afford to have paintings By the artists you like hanging on your walls Well, worry no more Head on over to IndianColors.com Indian Colors is a company that licenses images Of the finest modern art From some of the best artists in India And adapts them into objects of everyday use These include wearable art Like stoles and shrugs Home decor like cushion covers and table runners And accessories like tote bags This allows art lovers to actually get fine art Into their homes at an accessible price And artists get royalties on sales Just like authors do What's more Indian Colors now has an exciting range of new products Including fridge magnets With some stunning motifs And salad bowls and platters made of mango wood Their artists include luminaries Like Babu Xavier Vazvo x Vazvo Brinda Miller Dilip Sharma Shruti Nelson And Pradeep Mishra They accept bulk orders For corporate and festival gifting But even if you want to buy Just for yourself or a friend Head on over to IndianColors.com That's colors with an O-U And if you want a 20% discount Apply the code IVM20 That's IVM for IVM Podcast IVM20 for a 20% discount At IndianColors.com Shruti, welcome to The Seen and The Unseen

speaker: Guest
message: Hello Hi Amit, it's great to be here

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Awesome Now you've also been writing About demonetization for a while In fact, you wrote a very trenchant piece With our friend Larry White Where you sort of rebutted Some of the arguments Which Jagdish Bhagwati and her co-writer Had made for demonetization What were your instincts When you first heard about it?

speaker: Guest
message: So my immediate instinct On demonetization was that It was simply a terrible idea So I remember writing about it Immediately after the event Maybe like five or seven days After the event My first op-ed on the piece Was published in Real Clear Market Somewhere end of November Maybe about three weeks After the event It just took a while To place the piece Because there was a lot of confusion Over what was happening We have a member at the same time On the same night Was the Trump election So I live in the United States And any column that you sent To any American newspaper Was just like There was too much other stuff going on Everyone was writing about Trump So even though I wrote it About maybe seven, eight days after Got published about three weeks after And it was pretty consistent To what I feel right now I made a few arguments then Which was that It assumes The demonetization policy Assumes that The black money is essentially held in cash Which my hunch then was That this is simply not true And the second part of the argument was India is fundamentally a cash economy Many people have made the Analogy of Cash in India Just like blood In the body And if you drain the cash in India It would basically kill the economy And the poor people As would happen If you drain the blood From the human system So those were sort of the arguments That I made And at that time What I was really concerned about Were the Economic costs of demonetization And I do want to add here That only bad Economists Make this distinction between Human costs and economic costs And say that the economic benefits Justify the human costs All economic benefits and costs Are human costs and benefits

speaker: Unknown
message: I agree, absolutely

speaker: Guest
message: But people dying Is not As you rightly pointed out Only foolish economists point out That when a poor person With no income dies The GDP per capita Goes up And you know When a human child is born Then the GDP per capita goes down So only terrible economists Make arguments like this So demonetization was no different There were a lot of Economists who made Terrible arguments And some of those arguments Were based on misinformation Right? They just made the wrong assumptions In terms of How much black money There was in the economy And how much money Or you know One time revenue Would be recovered From the demonetization policy So one kind of bad economics Was grounding it On poor assumptions The second kind of bad economics Was just grounding it On poor reasoning Which is The idea that You know All these costs That you're talking about Which is people dying People not able to pay Their hospital bills Or get their children married Poor people losing Their entire life savings Right? Even rich people Who are running From pillar to post Trying to avoid the tax Trying to spend A lot of resources To avoid the tax Of demonetization All of these are Huge economic costs So These were basically The two different kinds Of responses From the bad economists But there were a lot of economists You Larry White Ajay Shah Myself Who basically You know Called a spade a spade And said demonetization Is a bad idea Because it's just Simply too costly

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Shruti You know both of us Look at the world Sort of through An economic lens Where we speak about Incentives and so on And we talk about The incentives On people in general When we talk about Public choice theory Do politicians And bureaucrats Also respond to incentives Do economists Also respond to incentives I mean I know This is not really Part of the subject Of this show But it's something That's interested me That you know Even economists Who should have Known better And who perhaps Did know better Like Jagdish Bhagwati Arvind Panagaria Came out in defense

speaker: Guest
message: Of demon What were the incentives That play there You know I'm really Not sure There were many Economists who got it wrong And like I said You know there are Two categories There are people Who relied on Bad information And there are people Who relied on Bad arguments And some people Relied on a combination Of both Jagdish Bhagwati Arvind Panagaria All of them Have written Extensively on Trade policy Right And when you Read their work On trade policy It is all grounded In the costs And benefits Of trade and protectionism Exactly the kind Of analysis One would do For demonetization So the way Protectionism Imposes a tax On people They would talk about What are the costs Of these tax And what are the Benefits of protectionism And who the benefits Go to They have very Clear excellent Economic analysis So I'm not Sure if It simply Didn't translate From one field Of economics To another You know Those arguments Were in trade And they simply Didn't understand What was going On with demonetization To apply the same Principles But they Didn't know If something Else was going On In all fairness Arvind Panagaria Never said

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Anything really About demonetization To my memory That's true I mean Bhagwati

speaker: Guest
message: Wrote a couple Of pieces And you in fact Rebutted one of them With Larry Yes So the piece That we rebutted Actually this is A good time To talk about it There are Two issues With respect To the failure Of demonetization To become Costly So these are The arguments You and I Have been making For a year And a half Which is You know The loss Of human life The loss Of human Livelihood Former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh Talked about It's going To lead To a drop Of 2% Of the GDP And it's Definitely Lost more Than 1% Like there Was No Cost In the sense That The RBI Was perfectly Prepared All the notes Were ready To transition From old notes To new notes All the ATM's And the banks Worked There was No confusion Any person Could have Gone And You know Traded Or switched Their currency From old To new And The Transition In that 60 day Period Really Go down Correct Right Now Is demonetization A good idea Right If we had Gotten it Right If it Wasn't The Indian State That Made The Transition But some Other Super State Which The Original 1500 Rupee Notes Their Legal Status Was revoked What Would Happen Is That People Would Deposit The Money In Banks To Switch To The New Notes And Those Who Are Not Going To Pay The Money In The Banks So For RBI Currency In Circulation Is A Liability So Every Rupee That Doesn't Come Back To The RBI Currency Is A Reduction In Liability Right And Therefore One Time Revenue Gain For The

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Government So This Is What They Were Hoping Would Happen Now There Were Different Estimates On Currency In Circulation In The

speaker: Guest
message: Economy So There Were These Estimates Going Around On How Much Of It Is Black Money And Remember It's Not Just About How Much Of It Is Running On Black Money Right Black Money Is Not Like Some Bad Thing In The Sense That The Money Itself Is Rotten Right So It's Just Money On Which Tax Has Not

message: Been

message: Paid Or The Full Tax Has Not Been Paid Now Most People Like There Were Members Of The Government Like Estimated At Between 10 And 30 Percent Right In
